title: Judgment against the Daughters of Zion
html:
We recall that 1:2-5a and 10-15 feature a courtroom scene, wherein the Lord pronounces a legal decision on the house of Israel. A similar scene, also with Israel as the accused, appears in 3:13-4:1, in which once again the Lord stands as both prosecutor and judge (3:13). Isa. 3:13-17 describes a heavenly courtroom scene where the Lord stands both to plead and to pronounce a judgment. The reason for the judgment is clear: "The Lord will enter into judgment" because the children of Israel mistreated the poor (3:14b), "beat" God's people (3:15), and were proud and "haughty" (3:16-23). The judgments of God described in 3:17-26 include the following: the Lord will smite the offenders with a scab on the head (3:17); he will take away their finery and showy materialism (3:18-24); and he will make them bald and cause them to burn, stink, wear rent clothes, fall in war, and become desolate (3:24-26). Isa. 3:24-26 seems to indicate that the phrase "daughters of Zion" (3:16) speaks not just against women but against all Israel, male and female. Another possible interpretation of the object of God's prophecy is that in 3:14-15, 25, he is talking to males and in 3:16-24 he is talking to females.

The Lord standeth up to plead,
and standeth to judge the people. (3:13)
The Lord will enter into judgment with the [elders] of his people,
and the princes thereof:
for ye have eaten up the vineyard
[and] the spoil of the poor in your houses. (3:14)
What mean[ye[?] Ye beat my people to pieces,
and grind the faces of the poor? saith the Lord God of hosts. (3:15)
Moreover, the Lord saith, Because the daughters of Zion are haughty,
and walk with stretched forth necks and [flirtatious] eyes,
walking [along in prancing manner], and [with ornaments jingling on their ankles]: (3:16)
Therefore the Lord will smite with a scab the crown of the head of the daughters of Zion,
and the Lord will [uncover their forehead]. (3:17)
In that day the Lord will take away [their finery:
the bangles and headbands and crescent necklaces, (3:18)
the earrings and bracelets and veils, (3:19)
the headdresses and ankle chains and sashes,
the perfume bottles and charms, (3:20)
the signet rings and nose rings, (3:21)
the fine robes and the capes and cloaks,
the purses (3:22) and mirrors,
and the linen garments and tiaras and shawls.] (3:23)
And it shall come to pass, instead of [fragrance] there shall be stink;
and instead of a [sash, a rope];
and instead of well set hair, baldness;
and instead of a [majestic robe], a girding of sackcloth;
[humiliation] instead of beauty. (3:24)
Thy men shall fall by the sword
and thy mighty in the war. (3:25)
And her [entrances] shall lament and mourn;
and she [shall be] desolate [and] shall sit upon the ground. (3:26)
And in that day, seven women shall take hold of one man, saying: We will eat our own bread, and wear our own apparel; only let us be called by thy name to take away our reproach. (4:1)
